paragraph: These three comparisons with a woman are to be found near each other on the same page. Mudjekeewis has, like a true hero, once more torn life from the jaws of death, from the all-devouring “terrible mother.” This deed, which, as we have seen, is also represented as a journey to hell, “night journey through the sea,” the conquering of the monster from within, signifies at the same time entrance into the mother’s womb, a rebirth, the results of which are perceptible also for Mudjekeewis. As in the Zosimos vision, here too the entering one becomes the breath of the wind or spirit. Mudjekeewis becomes the west wind, the fertilizing breath, the father of winds.[634] His sons become the other winds. An intermezzo tells of them and of their love stories, of which I will mention only the courtship of Wabuns, the East Wind, because here the erotic wooing of the wind is pictured in an especially beautiful manner. Every morning he sees a beautiful girl in a meadow, whom he eagerly courts:“Every morning, gazing earthward,         Still the first thing he beheld there         Was her blue eyes looking at him,         Two blue lakes among the rushes.”The comparison with water is not a matter of secondary importance, because “from wind and water” shall man be born anew.“And he wooed her with caresses,         Wooed her with his smile of sunshine,         With his flattering words he wooed her,         With his sighing and his singing,         Gentlest whispers in the branches,         Softest music, sweetest odors,” etc.In these onomatopoetic verses the wind’s caressing courtship is excellently expressed.[635]
question: In the context of the Mudjekeewis legend, what does the comparison of Mudjekeewis to a hero signify?
answer: The comparison of Mudjekeewis to a hero signifies that he has successfully rescued life from a dangerous situation, represented as tearing life from the jaws of death and conquering a monster. This act is also depicted as a journey to hell, a "night journey through the sea," and signifies entering the mother’s womb, leading to a rebirth.
